document.docAuthor: Cao, Huan-Xi, Salle, John La & Zhu, Chao-Dong
document.masterDocTitle: Chinese species of Pediobius Walker (Hymenoptera: Eulophidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Chinese species of Pediobius Walker (Hymenoptera: Eulophidae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:

–119; ♀♂. Syntypes ♀♂, BMNH, not examined.

Pediobius illiberidis Liao, in
Liao et al. 1987
: 111
; ♀³. Holotype ♀, IZCAS, examined. Syn. n.

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Scutellum longitudinally striate, but sculpture weak and evanescent medially, and sometimes almost smooth and forming a very narrow smooth median band ( Figs 20 a–b). Metatibial spur fuscous apically, hardly or slightly exceeding the apex of basal tarsomere ( Fig. 20 k).

specimens of
P . iliberidis
: Lectotype
♀ , CHINA , Shaanxi , Baoji , Sunligou ,
11.VI.1973
, ex .
Illiberis pruni Dyar
;
paratype
1♂ , same data as the lectotype .
Determined specimens compared ( ANIC )
:
2♂ , TURKEY : Tosya , 1975, coll. R. Samlidere , det. Bouček.

Biology.
Pediobius pyrgo
has been recorded as both a primary and a secondary parasitoid with a very wide host range. In China , this species was mainly recorded as a primary parasitoid of larvae or pupae of moths ( Lepidoptera ), including the records known so far as follows:
Amata
sp. ( Ctenuchidae );
Gelechia pinguinella Trietschke
and Gelechiidae sp. ( Gelechiidae ); Geometridae sp. ( Geometridae );
Phyllocnistis citrella Stainton
( Gracilariidae ); Heliodinidae sp. ( Heliodinidae );
Dendrolimus
spp. and
Malacosoma
spp. ( Lasiocampidae ); Lymantridae sp. ( Lymantridae );
Aporia crataegi
(L.). ( Pieridae );
Smerinthus planus Walker
and Sphingidae sp. ( Sphingidae );
Adoxophyes orana Fischer & Roslerstamm
,
Homona coffearia Meyrick
and Tortricidae spp ( Tortricidae );
Yponomeuta polystinellus Felder.
( Yponomeutidae );
Illiberis tenuis Butler
and
Illiberis pruni Dyar
( Zygaenidae ). Six females were recorded from
Eulecanium kuwanai Kanda
( Hemiptera : Coccidae ), which requires further confrimation. Additionally, under the name of
P. illiberidis
,
P . pyrgo
has been recorded from
Acrocercops astaurota Meyrick
( Lepidoptera : Gracilariidae ) and
Leucoptera scitella
L. ( Lepidoptera : Lyonetidae), and also recorded from
Clostera anachoreta (
Liao et al. 1987
)
. Besides, it has been recorded as a secondary parasitoid from
Pteromalus puparum
L. ( Hymenoptera : Pteromalidae ), Pteromalidae sp. ( Hymenoptera : Pteromalidae ) and
Apanteles
spp. ( Hymenoptera : Braconidae ) in China .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 20.
Pediobius pyrgo (Walker, 1839)
. a–b: female, body in dorsal view; c: female, body in lateral view; d: male, body in dorsal view; e: male, body in lateral view; f: female, fore wing; g: male, antenna; h: female, antenna; i: female, fore leg; j: female, mid leg; k: female, hind leg. Scale bar: a–e, 0.5 mm; f, 0.4 mm; g–h, 0.1 mm; i–k, 0.2 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution in China .
Widely distributed in China : Anhui , Beijing , Fujian , Gansu , Guangxi , Heilongjiang , Hunan ,
Inner Mongolia
, Jilin , Jiangsu , Jiangxi , Liaoning , Ningxia , Qinghai , Shaanxi , Shandong , Shanxi , Shanghai , Sichuan , Taiwan , Xinjiang , Yunnan , Zhejiang .

Remarks.
Pediobius pyrgo
has a very wide distribution in China . Like
P . bruchicida
, it also shows intraspecific variation in the relative width of smooth median band of scutellum. Besides, there are also variations on mesoscutum having reticulations broad or small, and scutellum having striations dense or coarse. Hansson (2002) stated that
P . pyrgo
has scutellum entirely reticulate. Although scutellum seems entirely striate for some specimens examined here, the median band of scutellum has reticulations very weak and even evanescent, which resembles a narrow smooth median band. Compared with female, male has reticulations more distinct medially.

Liao et al. (1987)
stated that
P. illiberidis
was very similar to
P . pyrgo
, from which it mainly differs in the following: toruli inserted at the level of lower eyes margin; F1 slightly longer than broad, F2 and F3 transverse; space between submedian carinae of propodeum broad; the basal two tarsomeres of hind leg white. However, all characters above are also fitted to
P . pyrgo
, which cannot be used to separate them. In addition, it seems unreliable for those characters to separate
P . pyrgo
from
P. illiberidis
given in the key of
Liao et al. (1987)
(couplet 2), e . g ., the ratio of gaster to mesosoma, and the ratio of length to width of each funicular segment. We do not find significant differences between
P . pyrgo
and
P. illiberidis
in these features. Based on our observations of determined specimens of
P. pyrgo
and type specimens of
P. illiberidis
, we regard
P. illiberidis
as a synonym of
P . pyrgo
.

Hansson (2002) and Taveras & Hansson (2015) stated that
P . pyrgo
has the posterior margin of dorsellum rounded. However, the specimens available to us have that tridentate. Differences with other members within the
pyrgo
-group are given in the key. See also remarks under
P. bruchicida
.
